title: Benchmarking fails with 3 requests
body:
Hi,
I am running a local flask instance on my mac. I thought I would see how flask stood up to apache benchmark (ab). I threw 10 requests with one concurrent user and it fails! 

Is this something thats expected?

ab -n10 -c1 -q http://127.0.0.1:5000/
This is ApacheBench, Version 2.3 <$Revision: 655654 $>
Copyright 1996 Adam Twiss, Zeus Technology Ltd, http://www.zeustech.net/
Licensed to The Apache Software Foundation, http://www.apache.org/

Benchmarking 127.0.0.1 (be patient)...apr_socket_recv: Connection reset by peer (54)
Total of 2 requests completed

In my debug console I see three requests:

127.0.0.1 - - [06/Nov/2012 21:41:20] "GET / HTTP/1.0" 200 -
127.0.0.1 - - [06/Nov/2012 21:41:20] "GET / HTTP/1.0" 200 -
127.0.0.1 - - [06/Nov/2012 21:41:20] "GET / HTTP/1.0" 200 -

and my code:

``` python
from flask import Flask
from flask import render_template, send_from_directory
import os

app = Flask(__name__)
app.debug = True

@app.route('/favicon.ico')
def favicon():
    return send_from_directory('.', 'favicon.ico')

@app.route("/")
def index():
  return render_template("index")

if __name__ == "__main__":
  app.run()
```

index:

``` html
<!DOCTYPE HTML>
<html>
  <head>
    <meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8">
    <title></title>

  </head>
  <body>

  </body>
</html>
```

comments_inline.body: Flask's built in web server is a toy.  Its provided for easy development. Benching the app while running on it is not very useful.

Whereas I agree with @boris317 that the server is "a toy", it should be able to handle many concurrent requests regardless of it being a development server. The failure is expected, though, since by default the server is run in single-threaded, single-process mode and will simply not be able to cope with all incoming connections of course.

The `run` method https://github.com/mitsuhiko/flask/blob/master/flask/app.py#L712 accepts a whole lot of options that get passed on to the Werkzeug server https://github.com/mitsuhiko/werkzeug/blob/master/werkzeug/serving.py#L604 these options include `processes` `threaded`.

Give these settings a try and I'm sure you'll find the server to be a little more satisfying toy. Let us know how it goes. And, of course, don't use it in production.

I noticed you set concurrent connections to 1, so you shouldn't have had any issues with so little connections. After several test on the single-threaded/single-process setup of the development server I noticed no issues with a large number of requests (not an empty application, connects to a database, and does some other pre- and post- request stuff).

> httperf --rate 100 --num-conns 100 --port 5000 --server 127.0.0.1
> httperf --client=0/1 --server=127.0.0.1 --port=5000 --uri=/ --rate=100 --send-buffer=4096 --recv-buffer=16384 --num-conns=100 --num-calls=1
> Maximum connect burst length: 1
> Total: connections 100 requests 100 replies 100 test-duration 4.375 s
> Connection rate: 22.9 conn/s (43.7 ms/conn, <=76 concurrent connections)

Are you perhaps running under Windows, behind some firewall maybe, or anything else? What is your setup?
If you're running under Linux can you please supply an `strace -f` of your python application as it tries to serve these requests, and an `strace -f` of your `ab` test, too. Thanks.

Thanks for helping.

I was on Lion, and read some bits about needing to patch ab. I actually
tried upgrading to Mountain Lion but it looks like ab is the same version.

I haven't tried httperf.

Understood that flask built in server is not ideal, even though I thought
that was a Werkzeug<sp> instance? What is the hardened, production way to
serve a Flask app?

I am just doing dev work at the moment, but maybe helpful to know for the
future.

Thanks,
Dave

For a production environment  maybe a flask wsgi on nginx or other
solutions is better than what flask provides

@bitwise I see, you should try another tool and see if the issue persists, but my tests show that the build-in server (which **is** powered by Werkzeug https://github.com/mitsuhiko/flask/blob/master/flask/app.py#L743) can withstand quite a bit in single-threaded/single-process mode and I should imagine it can do more with `threading` and `processes` settings altered to non-defaults.

If your problem persists with other tools (try out http://pypi.python.org/pypi/httperfpy/) I'll guide you on providing a `dtrace` (available on OSX) to see what exactly is happening.

If all goes well feel free to shut this issue down as resolved. Good luck!

P.S. For production deployment check out http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/deploying/

I know this is several years later, but for anyone else stumbling on this, I have moved to use [boom](https://github.com/rakyll/boom), it provides some nice dist charts:

```
boom -n 1000 -c 10 http://localhost:5000
Summary:
  Total:    15.7435 secs
  Slowest:  0.2194 secs
  Fastest:  0.0185 secs
  Average:  0.1566 secs
  Requests/sec: 63.5184
  Total data:   450000 bytes
  Size/request: 450 bytes

Status code distribution:
  [200] 1000 responses

Response time histogram:
  0.018 [1] |
  0.039 [1] |
  0.059 [1] |
  0.079 [2] |
  0.099 [0] |
  0.119 [1] |
  0.139 [2] |
  0.159 [729]   |∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎
  0.179 [213]   |∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎∎
  0.199 [26]    |∎
  0.219 [24]    |∎

Latency distribution:
  10% in 0.1469 secs
  25% in 0.1500 secs
  50% in 0.1540 secs
  75% in 0.1599 secs
  90% in 0.1696 secs
  95% in 0.1794 secs
  99% in 0.2115 secs
```
The dev server is meant for single-client and local development/testing. There is no real point in benchmarking a server that is not meant for anything resembling production usage.

I meant that more for general  benching, sorry for not being clear! I saw a similar issue even against Gunicorn and part of it is due to the response lengths possibly changing (this can be disabled with the `-l` option in Apache).
